page.text: Study Area
Study Area
Safety Study
October 2011
The purpose of this safety study is to identify the crash problems, determine possible
countermeasures that may reduce the crash frequency as well as congestion as it relates to
access management. In addition, review the signal timing along the section study area
and recommend any necessary changes to improve safety and maintain good levels of
service with acceptable delays to the driving public.
The study section of U.S. 20 (Mentor Avenue) in the City of Mentor, Ohio is a 2.61-mile
segment with 625 crashes within the years of 2007 and 2009 (3 years) resulting in a
corridor crash rate of 10.22 crashes per million vehicle miles traveled (based on an
ODOT 2008 ADT estimate of 21,390 vehicles per day). This includes approximately 400
feet of each intersecting roadway along Mentor Avenue. The section is #83 on the 2009
HSP Non-Freeway List (2007-2009). The majority of the crashes were rear end crashes
(42%) or angle crashes (23%) occurring corridor wide.
U.S. 20 is classified as an urban principle arterial and runs east and west with a speed
limit of 35 mph within the study area. There are thirteen signalized intersections within
the study limits. From west to east these intersections are Acacia Avenue, Hart Street,
Southwood Drive, Jackson Street/Little Mountain Road, Heinen’s Market driveway,
Shady Lane, Hopkins Road, western K-Mart driveway, eastern K-Mart driveway, Wal-
Mart driveway, Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road, Wayside Drive, and Old Johnnycake
Ridge Road. These signals are currently interconnected through a closed loop system.
The major intersections within the corridor are Jackson Street/Little Mountain Road,
Hopkins Road, Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road, and Old Johnnycake Ridge Road. See
Figures 2 through 12 following the body of the report for the Conditions Diagrams.
The main crash type within the study area was rear end crashes with two hundred and
sixty-three crashes (42.1%). There were one hundred and forty-two angle crashes
(22.7%) and eighty-seven left-turn crashes (13.9%). The remainder of the crashes were
seventy-six (12.2%) sideswipe – passing crashes, seventeen (2.7%) fixed object crashes,
fourteen (2.2%) sideswipe – meeting crashes, twelve (1.9%) bicycle crashes, seven
(1.1%) backing crashes, five (0.8%) head on crashes, and two (0.3%) pedestrian crashes.
Although the crashes are occurring corridor wide at intersections as well as at mid-block
locations, there are nine specific locations in which the crashes are concentrated. These
areas contain fifteen or more crashes that are considered to be attributed to the conditions
in that area. For instance, forty-four crashes are contributed to the U.S. 20 intersection
with Hopkins Road. This includes the crashes within the intersection as well as those
occurring as the vehicles are approaching the intersection. These top crash locations and
their possible causes are as follows:
Safety Study
October 2011
1. U.S. 20 & Discount Drug Mart signalized intersection (18 crashes)
a. Poor signal visibility
b. Skewed alignment on U.S. 20 causing poor visibility of opposing vehicles
c. Lack of dedicated left-turn lanes
2. U.S. 20 & Hopkins Road signalized intersection (44 crashes)
a. Insufficient clearance intervals
b. Slippery roadway surface
3. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Hopkins Road and the western K-Mart
signalized intersection (25 crashes)
a. Slippery roadway surface
b. Lack of access management
c. Lack of middle two-way left-turn lane (TWLTL)
4. U.S. 20 & the eastern K-Mart signalized intersection (17 crashes)
a. Insufficient clearance intervals
b. Slippery roadway surface
5. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Wal-Mart and Heisley Road/Chillicothe
Road (21 crashes)
a. Congestion from nearby signalized intersections
b. Full access driveways in congested traffic conditions
6. U.S. 20 & Heisley Road signalized intersection (55 crashes)
a. Poor signal visibility
b. Insufficient clearance intervals
c. Congestion
7. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Heisley Road and Wayside Drive (22
crashes)
a. Slippery roadway surface
b. Lack of middle TWLT
c. Lack of access management
8. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Wayside Drive and Old Johnnycake
Ridge Road (29 crashes)
a. Congestion from nearby signalized intersections
b. Lack of access management
9. U.S. 20 & Old Johnnycake Ridge Road signalized intersection (71 crashes)
a. Skewed alignment on U.S. 20
b. Congestion
c. Slippery Roadway surface
The proposed countermeasures can be categorized in three improvement phases, which
are the short-term, medium-term, and long-term phases. The short-term phase
improvements should be implemented within one year. The medium-term phase
improvements are intended for one to five years and the long-term phase improvements
are intended for over five years.
Safety Study
October 2011
The short-term phase recommendations include:
Review signal head alignments throughout the corridor to ensure optimal signal
visibility.
Revise the local timings including the yellow and all-red times for each
intersection corridor wide. The current yellow and all-red times are set between
3.0 seconds to 3.8 seconds and 0.7 seconds to 2.0 seconds respectively. The
recommended changes would be to increase the all-red times to 1.5 seconds for
left-turn movements and side-street movements and 2.0 seconds for the mainline
movements. The yellow intervals could be extended to 3.5 seconds and 4.0
seconds.
Consider a Signal Progression Study to determine the optimal timing inputs for a
coordinated signal system to improve traffic progression through the corridor.
The existing signals are LED; however, it is recommended that backplates be
added corridor wide. It should be noted that the addition of backplates may
involve additional work to ensure adequate strength of the existing infrastructure
to carry the proposed additional load. For this reason these elements have not
been included in the cost estimate or rate-of-return analysis.
Consider additional signal heads on the signal poles where applicable (where
increased rear end crashes are occurring and/or signal visibility could be
improved). Specific locations where it is recommended to add signal heads are as
follows:
o
Southeast corner of the Discount Drug Mart signal for eastbound vehicles
(3-Section signal head).
o
Northwest corner of the Heinen’s Market signal for eastbound vehicles (3-
Section signal head).
o
Northwest corner of the Hopkins Road signal for southbound vehicles (3-
Section signal head).
o
Southeast corner of the western K-Mart signal for eastbound vehicles (5-
Section signal head for eastbound right-turn overlap).
o
Northwest corner of the Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road signal for
westbound, northbound, and southbound vehicles. The westbound and
northbound vehicle signal heads shall be 3-Section signal heads and could
be mounted on the signal pole. The southbound signal head should be a 3-
Section signal head and could be mounted on the back of the mast arm to
face the southbound traffic.
o
Southwest corner of Old Johnnycake Ridge Road signal for southbound
vehicles as well as westbound vehicles (5-Section signal heads for the
westbound left-turn phase and the southbound right-turn overlap).
Consider running skid tests at the following locations due to several accidents
under wet pavement conditions:
o
The westbound approach at the Hopkins Road signalized intersection
o
The eastbound and westbound travel lanes between Hopkins Road and the
western K-Mart driveway
Safety Study
October 2011
o
The eastbound and westbound approaches at the eastern K-Mart drive
signalized intersection.
o
The
eastbound
and
westbound
travel
lanes
between
Heisley
Road/Chillicothe Road and Wayside Drive.
o
The eastbound and northbound approaches at the Old Johnnycake Ridge
Road signalized intersection.
Install “Left Turn Signal” sign for the left-turn signals for vehicles traveling
southbound on Heisley Road.
Change the phasing at the Old Johnnycake Ridge Road intersection so that the
westbound left-turn phase is leading and protected (3-section signal head) only
while the eastbound left-turn phase is lagging (5-section signal head). Another
option would be to change the eastbound left-turn phase to protected only (3-
section signal head). (A 4-section signal head with flashing yellow arrow could
be used in lieu of the 3-section signal head; however, if the 4-section is preferred
it should be introduced corridor wide which would involve the installation of
additional signal heads to maintain two signal heads for the through lanes.)
The estimated 2010 cost for the short-term improvements would be $21,900.
The medium-term phase recommendations include:
Install a right-in/right-out island at the driveway between Marion Drive and the
Heinen’s Market signal (see Figure 27 following the body of the report).
Install right-in/right-out drives for the driveways on the west side of Old
Johnnycake Ridge Road near the U.S. 20 signalized intersection (see Figure 26
following the body of the report).
Install a center median on the eastbound approach to Old Johnnycake Ridge
Road. The median should extend back to approximately the Qdoba location
(9552 Mentor Avenue). With the median only extended back to this location,
access can still be maintained by connecting the Qdoba parking lot with the lot
immediately east of it which access both U.S. 62 and Old Johnnycake Ridge
Road. This should be considered a temporary maintenance of access and a long-
term solution would be to develop a service road to provide an access road for the
businesses on the south side of U.S. 20 (see Figure 26 following the body of the
report).
Install a center median between the signalized intersection at the Wal-Mart drive
and the Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road signalized intersection. A service road
exists north of U.S. 20 and the driveways on the south side can be connected to
maintain access on both sides of the roadway with full access available from
Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road. This should be considered a temporary
maintenance of access on the south side of U.S. 20 and a long-term solution
would be to develop a service road to provide an access road for these businesses
that would likely run from Chillicothe Road to the K-Mart lot to the west (see
Figure 25 following the body of the report).
Safety Study
October 2011
Install a new mast arm on the southwest corner of the Heisley Road/Chillicothe
Road intersection for the southbound approach signal heads. The existing mast
arm is located on the southeast corner and does not extend far enough for optimal
signal head alignment (see Figure 25 following the body of the report).
Install countdown pedestrian signal heads corridor wide.
Consider conducting a roundabout feasibility study for the intersections along
U.S. 20 where the implementation of service roads is infeasible. The study would
include conceptual drawings of the roundabouts, right-of-way needed to build a
roundabout, and engineering and construction costs to build the roundabout.
The estimated 2010 cost for the medium-term improvements would be $233,684. The
rate of return for these medium-term benefits would be 360%, with an annual benefit of
$841,905. It should be noted that the cost of the roundabout feasibility study was not
included in the rate-of-return analysis. The cost of the roundabout feasibility study is
estimated to cost $50,000 and should include an analysis of up to six roundabouts.
The long-term phase recommendations include:
Install a center raised median throughout the corridor to limit mid-block conflict
points. To maintain access to the businesses along Mentor Avenue access
management techniques such as service roads should be implemented. At a
minimum, a median should be installed between Hopkins Road and the western
K-Mart driveway and between Jackson Street/Little Mountain Road and the
Heinen’s Market driveway as these areas display a need for access management
and would require service roads.
Consider installing roundabouts at intersections where service roads are infeasible
due to excessive cost and/or right-of-way acquisition. The roundabouts take the
place of service roads due to the ability for vehicles to perform a u-turn in order to
access businesses along the opposing lanes of travel.
Re-align U.S. 20 at the Old Johnnycake Ridge Road intersection to remove the
sharp skew at the intersection.
The estimated 2010 cost for these long-term improvements would be $1,961,511. The
rate of return for these long-term benefits would be 161%, with an annual benefit of
$3,150,669. It should be noted that the cost for installing a roundabout, service roads,
and the re-alignment of U.S. 20 at Old Johnnycake Ridge Road was not included in this
analysis due to the fact that several unknown factors would be involved including right-
of-way and utility impacts.
Safety Study
October 2011
Install a center two-way left-turn lane throughout the corridor to remove left-
turning vehicles from the through lanes. This alternative does not restrict mid-
block movements; therefore, with this alternative, driveways accessing Mentor
Avenue should be limited to right-in/right-out only and service roads should be
utilized to force other movements back to the signalized intersections. At a
minimum, U.S. 20 should be widened for a middle TWLTL or dedicated left-turn
lanes at the Discount Drug Mart driveway signal and in the area of Old Heisley
Road.
Re-align U.S. 20 at the Old Johnnycake Ridge Road intersection to remove the
sharp skew at the intersection.
The estimated 2010 cost for these long-term improvements would be $1,906,577. The
rate of return for these long-term benefits would be 14%, with an annual benefit of
$290,575. It should be noted that the cost for the re-alignment of U.S. 20 at Old
Johnnycake Ridge Road was not included in this analysis due to the fact that several
unknown factors would be involved including right-of-way and utility impacts.
Safety Study
October 2011
The study section of U.S. 20 (Mentor Avenue) in the City of Mentor, Ohio is a 2.61-mile
segment with 625 crashes within the years of 2007 and 2009 (3 years) resulting in a
corridor crash rate of 10.22 crashes per million vehicle miles traveled (based on an
ODOT 2008 ADT estimate of 21,390 vehicles per day). This includes approximately 400
feet of each intersecting roadway along Mentor Avenue. The section is #83 on the 2009
HSP Non-Freeway List (2007-2009). The majority of the crashes were rear end crashes
(42%) or angle crashes (23%) occurring corridor wide. The study limits include thirteen
signalized intersections as well as several unsignalized intersections.
U.S. 20 is classified as an urban principle arterial and runs east and west with a speed
limit of 35 mph within the study area. There are thirteen signalized intersections within
the study limits. From west to east these intersections are Acacia Avenue, Hart Street,
Southwood Drive, Jackson Street/Little Mountain Road, Heinen’s Market driveway,
Shady Lane, Hopkins Road, western K-Mart driveway, eastern K-Mart driveway, Wal-
Mart driveway, Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road, Wayside Drive, and Old Johnnycake
Ridge Road. The major intersections within the corridor are Jackson Street/Little
Mountain Road, Hopkins Road, Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road, and Old Johnnycake
Ridge Road.
Mentor Avenue currently consists of a 4-lane cross-section with two lanes of travel in
each direction. This is the roadway cross-section throughout the corridor (excluding
dedicated turn lanes at intersections) except for certain locations where a middle two-way
left-turn lane (TWLTL) is introduced. This 5-lane cross-section occurs between Jackson
Street/Little Mountain Road and Fox Mill Road, between the signalized Wal-Mart
Safety Study
October 2011
driveway and Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road, and between Wayside Drive and Old
Johnnycake Ridge Road. The section contains street lighting throughout the corridor and
the pavement condition appears to be acceptable; however, there were several accidents
that occurred on wet pavement therefore skid tests are recommended. See Figures 2
through 12 following the body of the report for the Conditions Diagrams.
There were 625 crashes between year 2007 and year 2009 (3 years) within the study
section of U.S. 20 (9.59 – 12.2) in Lake County. The crash data summary is in Appendix
A and includes the crash data submitted from ODOT. Figures 13 through 23 show the
Collision Diagrams for all three years. It should be noted that certain crashes were
removed from this analysis including five crashes involving animals and four crashes
where vehicles struck a manhole cover while the roadway was under repair. These
crashes have been removed as their causes are outside of the normal roadway conditions.
Crash Data Summary: Total = 625

Section Crash Rate = 10.22 crashes per million vehicle miles traveled.
The section crash rate was calculated using an average daily traffic (ADT) of 21,390
vehicles per day (vpd). This number was determined using the ODOT Traffic Maps as

Safety Study
October 2011
the ADT located on the ODOT Traffic Survey Report was determined in 2008 while the
roadway was under construction.
The main crash type within the study area was rear end crashes with two hundred and
sixty-three crashes (42.1%). There were one hundred and forty-two angle crashes
(22.7%) and eighty-seven left-turn crashes (13.9%). The remainder of the crashes were
seventy-six (12.2%) sideswipe – passing crashes, seventeen (2.7%) fixed object crashes,
fourteen (2.2%) sideswipe – meeting crashes, twelve (1.9%) bicycle crashes, seven
(1.1%) backing crashes, five (0.8%) head on crashes, and two (0.3%) pedestrian crashes.
Of the 625 total crashes, 483 (77.3%) were property damage crashes, 140 (22.4%) were
injury crashes, and 2 (0.3%) crashes were fatal. One fatal crash involved a motorcyclist
who had been drinking and lost control at the east entrance to the Mentor Commons
Shopping Center (9200 Mentor Avenue) and struck the curb. The second fatal crash was
a rear end crash involving five vehicles on the eastbound approach to the Old Johnnycake
Ridge Road intersection. Three hundred and ninety-seven (63.5%) crashes, including
both fatality crashes, occurred on dry pavement with no adverse weather conditions. The
pedestrian and bicycle accidents cannot be attributed to any roadway deficiency and are
primarily due to lack of attention from the driver and/or the pedestrian. It should be
noted that nearly 43% of the crashes occurred while traveling eastbound. See Figures 13
through 23 following the body of the report for the Collision Diagrams.
Although the crashes are occurring corridor wide at intersections as well as at mid-block
locations, there are nine specific locations in which the crashes are concentrated. These
areas contain fifteen or more crashes that are considered to be attributed to the conditions
in that area. For instance, forty-four crashes are contributed to the U.S. 20 intersection
with Hopkins Road. This includes the crashes within the intersection as well as those
occurring as the vehicles are approaching the intersection. These top crash locations are
as follows:
1. U.S. 20 & Discount Drug Mart signalized intersection (18 crashes)
2. U.S. 20 & Hopkins Road signalized intersection (44 crashes)
3. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Hopkins Road and the western K-Mart
signalized intersection (25 crashes)
4. U.S. 20 & the eastern K-Mart signalized intersection (17 crashes)
5. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Wal-Mart and Heisley Road/Chillicothe
Road (21 crashes)
6. U.S. 20 & Heisley Road signalized intersection (55 crashes)
7. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Heisley Road and Wayside Drive (22
crashes)
8. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Wayside Drive and Old Johnnycake
Ridge Road (29 crashes)
9. U.S. 20 & Old Johnnycake Ridge Road signalized intersection (71 crashes)
Safety Study
October 2011
Four-hour turning movement counts were completed in January 2011 for the signalized
intersections of U.S. 20 at Old Johnnycake Ridge Road, Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road,
and Hopkins Road. These counts were then projected out twenty years and analyzed.
The DLZ traffic counts can be found in Appendix B.
Capacity is the volume of traffic that can pass through a roadway facility in a given
amount of time (vehicles/hour). The concept of Level of Service (LOS) is a qualitative
measure of the operation of the traffic flow. LOS considers such factors as speed, travel
time, freedom to maneuver, traffic interruptions, driver inconvenience, safety and delay.
For different transportation facilities, the LOS is based on different measures of
effectiveness.
Signalized intersections are measured for average control delay in seconds per vehicle.
Control delay includes initial deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped delay and
final deceleration delay. The delay measurement for vehicles at a signalized intersection
is a combination of driver discomfort, driver frustration and lost travel time.
The LOS rating system as described in the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual gives a value
of A through F to each type of roadway facility representing the best to worst traffic
conditions. When designing for roadway improvements, it is desirable to accommodate
design peak hour volumes at a LOS C or D. Table 1 summarizes the levels of service for
signalized intersections.

text.b: Table 1: Level of Service Criteria for Signalized Intersections

page.text: Level of Service
Average Control Delay
A
Less than 10.0 Seconds/Vehicle
B
10.1 to 20.0 Seconds/Vehicle
C
20.1 to 35.0 Seconds/Vehicle
D
35.1 to 55.0 Seconds/Vehicle
E
55.1 to 80.0 Seconds/Vehicle
F
Greater than 80.0 Seconds/Vehicle
The signals in the study area are currently in coordination. The signalized intersections
are interconnected through a closed loop system via an on street master. Existing signal
timings were provided to DLZ that declared several separate timings plans for the
interconnected signals. The timing plans can be found in Table 2 on the following page.
Traffic counts were conducted at 3 major intersections along U.S. 20. Those
intersections are the focus of the operational analysis.
Safety Study
October 2011

text.b: Table 2: Timing Plan Based on Time Of Day

page.text: Time Of Day
Timing Plan
Cycle Length
90 seconds

120 seconds

Free
DLZ conducted traffic counts in January 2011 during the two peak traffic periods in the
study area, the AM and PM peaks. The turning movement counts were conducted at the
three major intersections in this corridor which are the U.S. 20 intersections with Hopkins
Road, Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road, and Old Johnnycake Ridge Road. The AM peak
hour traffic occurs between 7:30 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. falling within timing plan 1/1/1,
which is a 90-second cycle length for the corridor. The PM peak hours occur between
4:00 p.m. and 5:45 p.m. (depending upon the intersection) and falls within timing plan
4/4/1, which is a 120-second cycle length for the corridor. These timing plans were
applied to the counts obtained by DLZ while the signal timings for the projected 20-year
traffic conditions were analyzed using existing and optimized timings using the computer
modeling program Synchro v7. Table 2 shows the results of the existing conditions
analyses.

text.b: Table 3: Intersection Level Of Service – Existing Conditions

page.text: Intersection of U.S. 20
(Mentor Avenue) &

*Results were determined using provided existing signal timings.
**Results were determined using signal timings optimized using Synchro v7. Cycle lengths
remained the same as the signals are part of a coordinated system.
The results of the operation analyses show no problematic areas at the major
intersections, as the LOS with the 20-year projected traffic remains acceptable at a LOS
of C for the PM peak periods. Although the capacity at the intersections appears
sufficient, there are still safety issues at these intersections that must be addressed. Table
3 below shows the capacity analyses for the proposed recommendations.
Safety Study
October 2011
Another alternative at this intersection would be to install a modern roundabout. The
RODEL traffic analysis of a two-lane roundabout during the AM and PM peak hour
showed a level of service A for the three intersections where turning movements counts
were conducted (Hopkins Road, Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road, & Old Johnnycakes
Ridge Road). The RODEL software is a fully interactive program for aiding in
roundabout design (the RODEL program uses regression equations from an extensive
research effort that included gathering data from 86 roundabouts). Two-lane approaches
would be recommended for the eastbound and westbound approaches at each intersection
while one-lane approaches for the northbound and southbound traffic would be sufficient
at Hopkins Road and Old Johnnycake Ridge Road. The Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road
intersection would require two-lane approaches in all directions; however, one lane could
go into two lanes just before the roundabout (northbound and southbound approaches
only).

text.b: Table 4: Intersection Level Of Service – Proposed Alternatives

page.text: Proposed Alternative
AM
PM
Lagging Permissive/Protected EBLT @ Old Johnnycake Ridge
Protected Only EBLT @ Old Johnnycake Ridge
Hopkins Road Roundabout
Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road Roundabout
Old Johnnycake Ridge Road Roundabout
*Roundabout alternatives include two entry lanes for EB/WB and one entry lane for
NB/SB with the exception of Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road where all four approaches
include two entry lanes.
The crash diagrams identified nine locations with elevated crash rates (fifteen or more
crashes). These locations were the focus of the proposed countermeasures. However,
there are also recommendations for the entire corridor. These recommendations include
signal backplates for all of the signals corridor wide (pole calculations would be required
to ensure the existing infrastructure could handle to proposed additional load). Also, it is
recommended that that yellow times and all-red times are revised throughout the project
area. The existing clearance intervals consist of a yellow time between 3.0 seconds and
3.8 seconds. The current all-red interval is between 0.7 seconds and 2.0 seconds. The
recommended timings (calculated based upon ODOT TEM, Section 403-2) are a yellow
interval between 3.5 seconds (left-turn phases and side-street phases) and 4.0 seconds
(mainline phases) and an all-red interval between 1.5 seconds (left-turn phases and side-
street phases) and 2.0 seconds (mainline phases). It is also recommended to install
countdown pedestrian signal heads at all intersections. These are all short-term, corridor
wide recommendations.
Some long-term corridor wide recommendations are to install a middle TWLTL (where
one does not currently exist) throughout the project area. This removes the left-turning
traffic from the mainline through lanes; however, this does little to restrict the movements
Safety Study
October 2011
from the many driveways. With the implementation of a center TWLTL, it is
recommended that the driveways along U.S. 20 be closed or limited to right-in/right-out
drives (driveways should be analyzed on an individual basis to determine the best plan of
action to improve safety in the corridor while still maintaining access to businesses).
Another alternative is to install a center raised median to limit the conflict points along
the mid-block areas. However, with the implementation of a center median, service roads
would be required in most areas to maintain access to the businesses along U.S. 20.
Another option is to install the center raised median as well as roundabouts at locations
where substantive right-of-way acquisition would be required and would not be feasible
to build the service roads. The implementation of a roundabout maintains access to
businesses with the ability for vehicles to safely perform a u-turn at the intersections to
access those businesses along the opposing lanes of traffic. The decision between
roundabouts and/or service roads should be analyzed in a section by section basis to
determine the best solution based on all of the involved factors including right-of-way
impacts, utility impacts, and engineering and construction costs.
The proposed countermeasures at the nine sections of elevated crash rates are as follows:
1. U.S. 20 & Discount Drug Mart signalized intersection (18 crashes) – This portion
of roadway experienced eight (44.4%) rear end crashes and four (22.2%) left-turn
crashes. The current roadway conditions are a four-lane cross-section on U.S. 20
with a skewed alignment between the eastbound and westbound approaches. To
alleviate the crash incidents in this location it is recommended to review the
signal timing and ensure optimal signal visibility. To improve signal visibility for
the eastbound vehicles it is recommended that a 3-section signal head be installed
on the signal pole on the southeast corner of the intersection. Another
recommendation would be to replace the existing 5-section signal head for
westbound vehicles with a 4-section signal head with a flashing yellow arrow.
Future improvements for this section include the addition of dedicated left-turn
lanes as well as the corridor improvements involving a center raised median with
service roads or a middle TWLTL with access control for the nearby driveways.
Safety Study
October 2011

text.b: Figure 2: Eastbound U.S. 20 @ Discount Drug Mart Signalized Intersection

page.text: 2. U.S. 20 & Hopkins Road signalized intersection (44 crashes) – This intersection
experienced thirty-two (72.7%) rear end crashes and eight (18.2%) left-turn
crashes representing over 90% of the crashes at the intersection. It is
recommended that the clearance intervals at this intersection be reviewed and
extended per the corridor recommendations. This will increase the clearance time
for vehicles passing through the intersection. It is also recommended to perform
skid tests on the westbound approach as many accidents are occurring with wet
pavement conditions. Another recommendation is to replace the 5-Section signal
heads with 4-Sections signal heads with flashing yellow arrows. Some long term
recommendations for this area are to install a 2-lane roundabout at this
intersection with the implementation of a center raised median between the
existing Hopkins Road signal and the western K-Mart signal. This alternative
will be discussed in further detail in the next crash section.
3. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Hopkins Road and the western K-Mart
signalized intersection (25 crashes) – This section of roadway experienced
thirteen (52.0%) rear end crashes many of which occurred under wet pavement
conditions; therefore, it is recommended to perform skid tests on U.S. 20. For
longer term countermeasures, it is recommended to apply some form of access
management techniques to limit the conflict points along U.S. 20. These
improvements could include widening the section to include a middle TWLTL.
This would remove the left-turning traffic from the through lanes but does not
restrict the movements from the many driveways along U.S. 20. It is
recommended that if a middle TWLTL is installed that the driveways be restricted
from full access via channelizing islands. A second alternative is to install a
Safety Study
October 2011
center raised median forcing the driveways to strictly right-in/right-out access
points. However, with the limitations on access points to the businesses along
U.S. 20, access roads should be introduced between the two signals to maintain
full access to businesses. An access road on the south side of U.S. 20 could be
feasible as the properties are mainly commercial and adequate space is available
to develop a service road. The north side of U.S. 20 however is mostly residential
and offers very little opportunity for an access road without extensive acquisition
requirements. To maintain business access while still limiting the mid-block
conflict points with a center median, it is recommended to install a two-lane
roundabout at both the Hopkins Road intersection and the western K-Mart
driveway intersection. With the introduction of the roundabouts at either end of
the median, vehicles are provided the ability to make a U-turn in the roundabout
to access those businesses on the opposing lanes of travel. See Figure 28
following the body of the report.
4. U.S. 20 & the eastern K-Mart signalized intersection (17 crashes) – Eight (47.1%)
of the crashes at this intersection were rear ends. Three (17.6%) crashes were due
to running a red light and nine (52.9%) occurred on wet pavement. The
recommendations at this intersection to review the clearance intervals and ensure
optimal signal visibility as well as perform skid tests on the approaches on U.S.
5. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Wal-Mart and Heisley Road/Chillicothe
Road (21 crashes) – Crashes in this section of roadway were mainly rear end and
angle with nine (42.9%) crashes each. The crashes in this section can be
attributed to congestion from nearby signals as well as vehicles attempting to exit
driveways between these signals. There appears to have been some access
management attempts on the north side of U.S. 20 with only three driveways, one
of which is a right-in/left-in/right-out driveway (crash data shows vehicles are still
attempting to make left-turns from the restricted drive). The two full access
drives are in close proximity to the signalized intersection at Heisley
Road/Chillicothe Road making left-turns very difficult and unsafe. The south side
of U.S. 62 consists of three driveways as well; however, all three are full access.
To limit these conflict points it is recommended that a center raised median be
installed to ensure the driveways are strictly right-in/right-out only. As previously
mentioned, access should be maintained to the businesses along U.S. 20 and to do
so, service roads or the installation of roundabouts would be necessary. There is
currently a service road north of U.S. 20 that can be utilized to access the
businesses on the north from Heisley Road. The parking lots to the southern
businesses are all connected except for the westernmost business which has a
small strip of grass between the two lots. This can be connected to maintain
access to these businesses as well; however, it is not ideal to force traffic into the
parking lots so an access road should be analyzed. A roundabout at Heisley
Road/Chillicothe Road would require two entry lanes and two exit lanes on U.S.
20 and two entry lanes and one exit lane on Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road.
Safety Study
October 2011
6. U.S. 20 & Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road signalized intersection (55 crashes) –
The majority of the crashes at this intersection were rear end crashes with thirty
(54.5%) crashes. This intersection is around 1,000 feet from the signal at the
Wal-Mart driveway and therefore the recommendations made for that mid-block
section will have an effect on this intersection as well. Aside from those
recommendations between the two signals, it is also recommended to revise the
signal timing as well as improve the signal visibility. Additional signal heads
could be added to the signal pole on the northwest corner. One 3-Section signal
head could be added to the signal pole for the northbound traffic on Chillicothe
Road. One 3-Section signal head could be added to the pole for the westbound
traffic on U.S. 20. Finally, a 3-Section signal head could be installed on the
reverse side of the mast arm for the southbound vehicles on Heisley Road. These
additional signal heads would improve visibility and likely reduce rear end
crashes.
7. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Heisley Road and Wayside Drive (22
crashes) – This location consisted of primarily rear end crashes with fifteen
(68.2%) crashes. Eleven (50.0%) crashes occurred with wet pavement so it is
recommended that pavement skid tests be performed on U.S. 20 in this portion of
roadway. This section of U.S. 20 consists of a four-lane cross-section. It is
recommended that the roadway be widened to include a middle TWLTL to
remove the left-turning vehicles from the mainline through lanes. There are
several driveways accessing U.S. 20 in this area that create conflict points for
exiting vehicles. It is recommended that if a middle TWLTL is introduced that
the driveways be analyzed to limit any unnecessary movements from the mid-
block driveways. This would require the implantation of service roads from
Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road to Wayside Drive to maintain access to those
businesses. Another option would be to install a center raised median to limit the
movements from the driveways. This alternative would need to be accompanied
by service roads to maintain alternate accesses to the businesses along U.S. 20 or
the installation of roundabouts at the two existing signals to provide drivers with
the option of a u-turn to access businesses on the opposing side of U.S. 20.
8. Mid-Block location on U.S. 20 between Wayside Drive and Old Johnnycake
Ridge Road (29 crashes) – Fourteen (48.3%) of the crashes were angle crashes
while thirteen (44.8%) were rear end crashes making up 93.1% of the crashes in
this section. All of the angle crashes occurred with vehicles exiting the driveways
on the south side of U.S. 20. It is recommended that the driveways in the area be
limited by right-in/right-out channelizing islands or a center raised median. The
north side of U.S. 20 contains a service road to access those businesses north of
U.S. 20. The southern businesses would require a service road between Wayside
Drive and Old Johnnycake Ridge Road however it should be noted that the
service road should tie into Old Johnnycake Ridge Road approximately 650 feet
back from the intersection near the end of the northbound left-turn lane. This is
recommended because of the high volume of northbound vehicles turning left at
Safety Study
October 2011
U.S. 20. The driveways on the east side of Old Johnnycake Ridge Road are
currently restricted to right-in/right-out and it is recommended that those drives
on the west side be restricted as well. A service road would require full access
and would be optimal further from the signalized intersection with U.S. 20.
9. U.S. 20 & Old Johnnycake Ridge Road signalized intersection (71 crashes) –
Thirty-two (45.1%) of the crashes at this intersection were rear ends and twenty-
seven (38.0%) of the crashes were left-turn crashes. Twenty-four of the left-turn
crashes occurred with an eastbound vehicle turning left. Recommendations for
this intersection are to review the signal timings and to perform skid tests on the
eastbound and northbound approaches. It is also recommended that a 3-Section
signal head be installed on the signal pole on the southwest corner for westbound
vehicles to improve signal visibility. The high amount of eastbound left-turn
crashes is contributed to the skewed intersecting angles of U.S. 20 with Old
Johnnycake Ridge Road. To alleviate these crashes in the short term it is
recommended that the signal phasing be adjusted so that the eastbound left-turn
phase is lagging (westbound left would be leading and protected only) or is
protected only. In the long-term, it is recommended to consider re-aligning U.S.
20 at this intersection to improve the intersecting angles on both approaches to
limit the skew angle.
The proposed countermeasures can be categorized in three improvement phases, which
are the short-term, medium-term, and long-term phases. The short-term phase
improvements should be implemented within one year. The medium-term phase
improvements are intended for one to five years and the long-term phase improvements
are intended for over five years.
The short-term phase recommendations include:
Review signal head alignments throughout the corridor to ensure optimal signal
visibility.
Revise the local timings including the yellow and all-red times for each
intersection corridor wide. The current yellow and all-red times are set between
3.0 seconds to 3.8 seconds and 0.7 seconds to 2.0 seconds respectively. The
recommended changes would be to increase the all-red times to 1.5 seconds for
left-turn movements and side-street movements and 2.0 seconds for the mainline
movements. The yellow intervals could be extended to 3.5 seconds and 4.0
seconds
Safety Study
October 2011
Consider a Signal Progression Study to determine the optimal timing inputs for a
coordinated signal system to improve traffic progression through the corridor.
The existing signals are LED; however, it is recommended that backplates be
added corridor wide. It should be noted that the addition of backplates may
involve additional work to ensure adequate strength of the existing infrastructure
to carry the proposed additional load. For this reason these elements have not
been included in the cost estimate or rate-of-return analysis.
Consider additional signal heads on the signal poles where applicable (where
increased rear end crashes are occurring and/or signal visibility could be
improved). Specific locations where it is recommended to add signal heads are as
follows:
o
Southeast corner of the Discount Drug Mart signal for eastbound vehicles
(3-Section signal head).
o
Northwest corner of the Heinen’s Market signal for eastbound vehicles (3-
Section signal head).
o
Northwest corner of the Hopkins Road signal for southbound vehicles (3-
Section signal head).
o
Southeast corner of the western K-Mart signal for eastbound vehicles (5-
Section signal head for eastbound right-turn overlap).
o
Northwest corner of the Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road signal for
westbound, northbound, and southbound vehicles. The westbound and
northbound vehicle signal heads shall be 3-Section signal heads and could
be mounted on the signal pole. The southbound signal head should be a 3-
Section signal head and could be mounted on the back of the mast arm to
face the southbound traffic.
o
Southwest corner of Old Johnnycake Ridge Road signal for southbound
vehicles as well as westbound vehicles (5-Section signal heads for the
westbound left-turn phase and the southbound right-turn overlap).
Consider running skid tests at the following locations due to several accidents
under wet pavement conditions:
o
The westbound approach at the Hopkins Road signalized intersection
o
The eastbound and westbound travel lanes between Hopkins Road and the
western K-Mart driveway
o
The eastbound and westbound approaches at the eastern K-Mart drive
signalized intersection.
o
The
eastbound
and
westbound
travel
lanes
between
Heisley
Road/Chillicothe Road and Wayside Drive.
o
The eastbound and northbound approaches at the Old Johnnycake Ridge
Road signalized intersection.
Install “Left Turn Signal” sign for the left-turn signals for vehicles traveling
southbound on Heisley Road.
Change the phasing at the Old Johnnycake Ridge Road intersection so that the
westbound left-turn phase is leading and protected (3-section signal head) only
while the eastbound left-turn phase is lagging (5-section signal head). Another
option would be to change the eastbound left-turn phase to protected only (3-
Safety Study
October 2011
section signal head). (A 4-section signal head with flashing yellow arrow could
be used in lieu of the 3-section signal head; however, if the 4-section is preferred
it should be introduced corridor wide which would involve the installation of
additional signal heads to maintain two signal heads for the through lanes.)
The estimated 2010 cost for the short-term improvements would be $21,900.
The medium-term phase recommendations include:
Install a right-in/right-out island at the driveway between Marion Drive and the
Heinen’s Market signal (see Figure 27 following the body of the report).
Install right-in/right-out drives for the driveways on the west side of Old
Johnnycake Ridge Road near the U.S. 20 signalized intersection (see Figure 26
following the body of the report).
Install a center median on the eastbound approach to Old Johnnycake Ridge
Road. The median should extend back to approximately the Qdoba location
(9552 Mentor Avenue). With the median only extended back to this location,
access can still be maintained by connecting the Qdoba parking lot with the lot
immediately east of it which access both U.S. 62 and Old Johnnycake Ridge
Road. This should be considered a temporary maintenance of access and a long-
term solution would be to develop a service road to provide an access road for the
businesses on the south side of U.S. 20 (see Figure 26 following the body of the
report).
Install a center median between the signalized intersection at the Wal-Mart drive
and the Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road signalized intersection. A service road
exists north of U.S. 20 and the driveways on the south side can be connected to
maintain access on both sides of the roadway with full access available from
Heisley Road/Chillicothe Road. This should be considered a temporary
maintenance of access on the south side of U.S. 20 and a long-term solution
would be to develop a service road to provide an access road for these businesses
that would likely run from Chillicothe Road to the K-Mart lot to the west (see
Figure 25 following the body of the report).
Install a new mast arm on the southwest corner of the Heisley Road/Chillicothe
Road intersection for the southbound approach signal heads. The existing mast
arm is located on the southeast corner and does not extend far enough for optimal
signal head alignment (see Figure 25 following the body of the report).
Install countdown pedestrian signal heads corridor wide.
Consider conducting a roundabout feasibility study for the intersections along
U.S. 20 where the implementation of service roads is infeasible. The study would
include conceptual drawings of the roundabouts, right-of-way needed to build a
roundabout, and engineering and construction costs to build the roundabout.
The estimated 2010 cost for the medium-term improvements would be $233,684. The
rate of return for these medium-term benefits would be 360%, with an annual benefit of
$841,905. It should be noted that the cost of the roundabout feasibility study was not
Safety Study
October 2011
included in the rate-of-return analysis. The cost of the roundabout feasibility study is
estimated to cost $50,000 and should include an analysis of up to six roundabouts.
The long-term phase recommendations include:
Install a center raised median throughout the corridor to limit mid-block conflict
points. To maintain access to the businesses along Mentor Avenue access
management techniques such as service roads should be implemented. At a
minimum, a median should be installed between Hopkins Road and the western
K-Mart driveway and between Jackson Street/Little Mountain Road and the
Heinen’s Market driveway as these areas display a need for access management
and would require service roads.
Consider installing roundabouts at intersections where service roads are infeasible
due to excessive cost and/or right-of-way acquisition. The roundabouts take the
place of service roads due to the ability for vehicles to perform a u-turn in order to
access businesses along the opposing lanes of travel.
Re-align U.S. 20 at the Old Johnnycake Ridge Road intersection to remove the
sharp skew at the intersection.
The estimated 2010 cost for these long-term improvements would be $1,961,511. The
rate of return for these long-term benefits would be 161%, with an annual benefit of
$3,150,669. It should be noted that the cost for installing a roundabout, service roads,
and the re-alignment of U.S. 20 at Old Johnnycake Ridge Road was not included in this
analysis due to the fact that several unknown factors would be involved including right-
of-way and utility impacts.
Install a center two-way left-turn lane throughout the corridor to remove left-
turning vehicles from the through lanes. This alternative does not restrict mid-
block movements; therefore, with this alternative, driveways accessing Mentor
Avenue should be limited to right-in/right-out only and service roads should be
utilized to force other movements back to the signalized intersections. At a
minimum, U.S. 20 should be widened for a middle TWLTL or dedicated left-turn
lanes at the Discount Drug Mart driveway signal and in the area of Old Heisley
Road.
Re-align U.S. 20 at the Old Johnnycake Ridge Road intersection to remove the
sharp skew at the intersection.
The estimated 2010 cost for these long-term improvements would be $1,906,577. The
rate of return for these long-term benefits would be 14%, with an annual benefit of
$290,575. It should be noted that the cost for the re-alignment of U.S. 20 at Old
Johnnycake Ridge Road was not included in this analysis due to the fact that several
unknown factors would be involved including right-of-way and utility impacts.
Safety Study
October 2011
